pytket.backends.ibm¶

Backends for connecting to IBM devices and simulators directly from pytket

class pytket.backends.ibm.IBMQBackend(backend_name: str, monitor: bool = True)¶
__init__(backend_name: str, monitor: bool = True)¶

A backend for running circuits on remote IBMQ devices.

Parameters

  • backend_name (str) – name of ibmq device. e.g. ibmqx4, ibmq_16_melbourne.

  • monitor (bool, optional) – Use IBM job monitor, defaults to True

Raises

ValueError – If no IBMQ account has been set up.

get_counts(circuit, shots, fit_to_constraints=True)¶

Run the circuit on the backend and accumulate the results into a summary of counts

Parameters

  • circuit – The circuit to run

  • shots – Number of shots (repeats) to run

  • fit_to_constraints (bool) – Compile the circuit to meet the constraints of the backend, defaults to True

  • seed – Random seed to for simulator

Returns

Dictionary mapping bitvectors of results to number of times that result was observed (zero counts are omitted)

run(circuit: pytket._circuit.Circuit, shots: int, fit_to_constraints: bool = True) → numpy.ndarray¶

Run the circuit on the backend and return results, optionally fitting the circuit to the constraints of the backend.

Parameters

  • circuit (Circuit) – The circuit to run

  • shots (int) – Number of shots (repeats) to run

  • fit_to_constraints (bool, optional) – Compile the circuit to meet the constraints of the backend, defaults to True

Returns

Table of shot results, each row is a shot, columns are ordered by qubit ordering. Values are 0 or 1 corresponding to qubit basis states.

Return type

numpy.ndarray

class pytket.backends.ibm.AerBackend(noise_model: qiskit.providers.aer.noise.noise_model.NoiseModel = None)¶
__init__(noise_model: qiskit.providers.aer.noise.noise_model.NoiseModel = None)¶

Backend for running simulations on Qiskit Aer Qasm simulator.

Parameters

noise_model (NoiseModel, optional) – Noise model to use in simulation, defaults to None.

get_counts(circuit, shots, fit_to_constraints=True, seed=None)¶

Run the circuit on the backend and accumulate the results into a summary of counts

Parameters

  • circuit – The circuit to run

  • shots – Number of shots (repeats) to run

  • fit_to_constraints (bool) – Compile the circuit to meet the constraints of the backend, defaults to True

  • seed – Random seed to for simulator

Returns

Dictionary mapping bitvectors of results to number of times that result was observed (zero counts are omitted)

run(circuit: pytket._circuit.Circuit, shots: int, fit_to_constraints=True, seed: int = None) → numpy.ndarray¶

Run a circuit on Qiskit Aer Qasm simulator.

Parameters

  • circuit (Circuit) – The circuit to run

  • shots (int) – Number of shots (repeats) to run

  • fit_to_constraints (bool, optional) – Compile the circuit to meet the constraints of the backend, defaults to True

  • seed (int) – random seed to for simulator

Returns

Table of shot results, each row is a shot, columns are ordered by qubit ordering. Values are 0 or 1, corresponding to qubit basis states.

Return type

numpy.ndarray

class pytket.backends.ibm.AerStateBackend¶
__init__()¶

Initialize self. See help(type(self)) for accurate signature.

get_operator_expectation_value(state_circuit, operator, shots=1000)¶

Calculates expectation value for an OpenFermion QubitOperator by summing over pauli expectations Note: This method is significantly faster using the ProjectQBackend than the AerStateBackend.

get_pauli_expectation_value(state_circuit, pauli, shots=1000)¶

Calculates expectation value for pauli term by preparing basis change circuit and measuring

get_state(circuit, fit_to_constraints=True)¶

Calculate the statevector for a circuit.

Parameters

circuit – circuit to calculate

Returns

complex numpy array of statevector

run(circuit, shots, fit_to_constraints=True)¶

Run the circuit on the backend and return results, optionally fitting the circuit to the constraints of the backend.

Parameters

  • circuit (Circuit) – The circuit to run

  • shots (int) – Number of shots (repeats) to run

  • fit_to_constraints (bool, optional) – Compile the circuit to meet the constraints of the backend, defaults to True

Returns

Table of shot results, each row is a shot, columns are ordered by qubit ordering. Values are 0 or 1 corresponding to qubit basis states.

Return type

numpy.ndarray

class pytket.backends.ibm.AerUnitaryBackend¶
__init__()¶

Initialize self. See help(type(self)) for accurate signature.

get_unitary(circuit, fit_to_constraints=True)¶

Obtains the unitary for a given quantum circuit

Parameters

  • circuit (Circuit) – The circuit to inspect

  • fit_to_constraints (bool, optional) – Forces the circuit to be decomposed into the correct gate set, defaults to True

Returns

The unitary of the circuit. Qubits are ordered with qubit 0 as the least significant qubit

run(circuit, shots, fit_to_constraints=True)¶

Run the circuit on the backend and return results, optionally fitting the circuit to the constraints of the backend.

Parameters

  • circuit (Circuit) – The circuit to run

  • shots (int) – Number of shots (repeats) to run

  • fit_to_constraints (bool, optional) – Compile the circuit to meet the constraints of the backend, defaults to True

Returns

Table of shot results, each row is a shot, columns are ordered by qubit ordering. Values are 0 or 1 corresponding to qubit basis states.

Return type

numpy.ndarray
